oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Asbury Methodist: church front and side view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of church front and side view in a rural residential area. A set of two-over-two sash windows flank double front doors. A transom window appears above the front doors. Gabled roof of the porch matches the larger gabled roof of the church. Brick facade of the church contains a gable vent overlaying a cross emblem. Side of the church features four two-over-two sash windows, a chimney, and back entrance with a wheelchair ramp. Church steeple contains a front vent and top cross.

Set originally in a Civil War-era log structure, the Asbury United Methodist Church was called Tate's Chapel after the first pastor, Rev. John C. Tate. A former slave, Tate gained prominence in Anderson County and was elected the clerk of the Circuit Court. The newly formed Methodist congregation appointed Tate as pastor and his name adorned the log church's cornerstone. Officially established on May 29, 1865, the church steadily gained membership, necessitating the construction of a new church. Once again, the church acquired a name from a church official. Dubbed the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church, the new church building survived until a fire in 1947. The third and current brick building was finished in 1950.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee;
churches; steeples; chimneys; sash windows; wheelchair ramps; transom windows;
